CrinComments: Sounds like an odd mashup of the HD600 and the Clear, in a good way.
An interesting in-between of DD and estat timbre, though tuning around the lower midrange may be off.
Some spiciness in the treble that is HD800-esque, but with a better midrange presentation.
Suffers from typical estat timbre and bass extension issues, but otherwise a very resolving and well-tuned headphone.
Arguably the least wonky-sounding of the mainstream Staxes, with resolution just shy of the flagship 009.
The legendary neutral reference. Slightly better clarity and imaging than the HD650.
Excellent imaging. Mostly neutral/flat tuning with an ever-so-slight tilt towards warmth.
Excellent tonal balance though limited by blunted notes and resolution.
One of the original Lambda models, and arguably the best tuned of the Lambda-styled Staxes.
High resolution planar that may be a little peaky in the treble for some.
A decent Utopia alternative for thinner wallets. Slightly warmer sound may be more pleasant for some.
Basically a brighter and slightly shoutier version of the OG; may be a little too intense for some.
A tad too shouty for my tastes, but far less offensive tonal characteristics than the average estat.
Closest thing to Harman thus far. Comes with a small upper treble spike and lacking raw resolution.
Expectedly Harman tuning but lacks a bit of bite in the upper midrange for "true Harman".
Well-executed reference-ish tuning with a slight treble emphasis.
The brightest and arguably harshest of the K7-- lineup, but still very competent overall.
Well-balanced tonality with good bass extension, just slightly hot in the upper-mids and treble.
Probably the most "mellow" of the Hifiman planars with the least resolving ability.
An even darker HD6X0. A comparatively muffled mess just barely propped up by its decent resolving ability.
Certainly a "mini-HD800" in terms of tonality only, however still far inferior in technical ability.
A rare combination of a warm-focused tonality with decent technicalities.
A massive improvement over its predecessor. Limited resolution and potentially intense tonality.
Pretty bog-standard V-shaped response with forward upper-midrange and decently high resolution.
Very reminiscent of the DT990.
Generally pleasing tuning, though a little honky and fatiguing in the treble.
Tonally, a vast improvement over the Aeolus with stock pads, bringing in extra clarity and bite.
Comes with an odd midrange dip. It's no HE6 replacement for sure.
Slight wonkiness around the lower midrange, but otherwise a capable planar headphone.
Highly resolving headphone with solid imaging capabilities, limited by its somewhat wonky tonality.
High treble-to-midrange contrast makes things sound shrill and borderline-sibilant.
Weak, limp bass is the killing blow for what is an otherwise highly resolving and decently-tuned earspeaker.
"Harman-inspired" tuning works decently well, though a myriad of small quirks ultimately screws its tonal balance.
Probably the most balanced tuning of the L-series, with the usual e-stat technicalities.
Far more tonally balanced than its open counterpart, whilst retaining its reverberant staging.
Clean, open sound reminsicent of the HD800, with a bit of midbass bloat and upper midrange shoutiness.
Honkier version of the standard L300.
Surprisingly competent for a decades-old set. Midrange is a little uneven but beats out many other modern TOTLs.
The original Hifiman. Midrange is a little too scooped out but remains competitive even today.
The usual "Foster biodyna dynamics" are at play here, with a somewhat fatiguing treble spike.
Generally "okay" tonality with some odd dips here and there. Lacking serious extension for a planar.
Kind of a "nothing headphone"; not bad, not great, just good enough to be okay.
Probably the best of the closed-back Focals. Some tuning refinements over the Stellia, though technically limited.
Lacks upper mids and resolution compared to its predecessor.
Definitely the least Audeze-sounding Audeze. A little quirky tonally, but nothing too offensive.
Subdued upper midrange with the odd treble spike makes this a weird headphone to listen to.
Bland and unexciting tuning with compressed staging and generally underperforming technicalities.
Non-existent sub-bass and poor resolution. But it's so well-tuned you may not even care.
A fairly competent warm-neutral monitor slightly held back by limited detail retrieval.
The most neutral of the M-series. Good tonality but still suffers from narrow imaging.
Punchy, energetic sound with decently balanced tonality. A pretty good beat-tracking monitor.
Basically a darker planar HD6X0, with equally closed-in staging and lacking the final resolving edge.
Good resolving ability and imaging, marred by its odd and honky midrange.
Middling technicalities, but for a gaming headphone its tonality is surprisingly balanced.
Well-balanced tonality with disappointing detailing and claustrophobic imaging.
Slightly midbass/lower-mid emphasised with good tonal balance, if rather "cheap"-sounding.
Tonality is somewhat off with peaks and dips here and there, but overall not a bad sounding headphone.
Perhaps the warmest of the Hifiman lineup. Not the most resolving.
A slight tonal improvement over the LCD-4, but also comes with a slight hit in resolution.

Model:
Abyss Diana Phi
Abyss Diana V2
CrinComments: Needs a little more upper midrange to balance out the honkiness. Good dynamic performance especially in the bass.
Tonally, a massive improvement over the previous version(s) though with the usual pitfalls of the Audeze house sound.
Probably the least wonky of the new Denons. Suffers from some mid-bass bloat.
An intense sound given its significant treble boost, but countered by a smooth lower-midrange bump.
As a gaming headphone, possibly the best technically though with the usual pitfalls of the Audeze house sound.
Not the worst Audeze in terms of tonality, but its tuning still doesn't live up to its technical capabilities.
Classic Audeze combo of solid resolution with a confusing lack of upper midrange.
Great tonality, sub-focused bass emphasis, bassy without being muddy. Average imaging and resolution.
Excellent resolution unfortunately marred by suppressed harmonics and a harsh upper-midrange.
Seems inspired by the tuning of the SR-009 with some minor improvements, though not enough to call it "good".
A very well-tuned monitor-style headphone, if heavily bottlenecked by narrow imaging and blunt hits.
Basically dead-neutral tuning, emphasis on "dead". Strong all-rounder whose only fault is not having that "wow-factor".
The legendary neutral reference. "Veiled" with a warm tilt (in comparison to HD600), and pretty terrible at imaging.
Extremely well-executed V-shaped tuning with no erronous peaks or dips. More mid-bassy than sub-bassy.
Solid tuning with a little treble spiciness for the daring. One of the better midrange planars out there.
Slightly more upper-mid-forward (read: shoutier) version of the K612.
One of the best tuned headphones available, only limited by its raw resolving ability.
The most neutral of the Foster biodyna models. If you want a little more balance than the Teaks.
Excellent dynamics with one of the best bass I've heard in a headphone, though the midrange can be a little harsh.
Almost "Harman" tuning with some undesirable mid-bass bloat.
Similar tuning to that of the Lambda Pro. Sonically identical between 404 and 404LE.
Similar tuning to that of the Lambda Pro.
Clean, resolving yet intense sound scratches the detail itch but is a little too edgy for long listens.
Surprisingly wide and spacious soundstage for a closed-back. Good low-end extension but rather shouty.
Very pleasant tonality but lacking that last bit of definition for true top-tier status.
Arguably the king of soundstage and raw detail, though at the cost of its infamous treble spike.
Treble peak may offend some, but otherwise very well balanced and natural tonality with decent technicalities.
Forward, in-your-face sound that's shouty and thin at the same time. A good reference for "true DF neutral".
Generally pleasing tuning with a little honkiness in the centre-midrange.
A little too sharp, a little too midbassy, but overall not the most offensive headphone out there.
A more bloated-sounding K712.
Lack of bass extension is its biggest dealbreaker of what would be an otherwise solid headphone.
Smooth, generally pleasing tonality throughout with no offensive characteristics.
More or less a HD599 with slightly worse resolution.
A tempered, almost bright-leaning planar (but not quite). Decent tonality and technical ability.
Choppy midrange response is its biggest turnoff, but otherwise a decent V-shaped headphone.
Somewhat warm midrange plagued with sharp and offensive treble.
A slightly worse-tuned B20, kinda.
Sizeable mid-bass bloat that's barely reigned in by an equally sizeable upper-midrange emphasis.
Fairly neutral monitor-style headphone with poor imaging and detail retrieval.
Holes in the midrange. Big spike in the treble. Strangely disjointed soundstage. Decently resolving.
Spicy sibilance and bloated bass are disappointments in what is otherwise an extremely dynamic headphone.
Passable tonality with dulled and blunted transients make for lacklustre detailing.
Detail and resolution worthy of being called "the best", marred by the tonally-off midrange.
A classic example of a highly resolving yet wonky sounding headphone. Needs more upper midrange.
Imaging as expected of an earspeaker configuration; surprisingly good tonality and expected bad extension.
A slightly more balanced TH900 with similar sibilance issues.
Feels like an attempt at Harman but ultimately missing the mark in the midrange tuning.
Middling technicalities with suppressed upper midrange.
Harman-ish tuning with a strong mid-bass presence and piercing upper treble response.

Model:
Abyss AB-1266 Phi CC
Abyss AB-1266 Phi
CrinComments: Sinfully addictive bass and treble reponse, but the midrange tonality needs a lot of work.
Classic Audeze combo of solid resolution with a confusing lack of upper midrange.
Strong contender for an excellent headphone, if not for the inexplicable hole in the mids.
Shouty and thin-sounding, though surprisingly competent imaging ability.
Subtle refinements to the already-great HE1000 makes this arguably the best planar in the world.
Mostly neutral, slight bass lift, highly resolving and natural both in tone and timbre. The world's best headphone.
Solid tuning with close to top-tier resolution. An inoffensive all-rounder that lives up to its reputation.
A planar that comes unnervingly close estat speed, but not quite. Solid technicalities with excellent tone.
